projects.name: Web I Psychology of Design Website
description: The final project for my Web I class was to create a website on a topic of our choice. I chose the psychology of design and pulled the color scheme for the website from an image of a peacock feather (which is also the site's favicon).

A description of some of the features of the website may be found on the resources page. The most interesting of these features may be found at the bottom of the color page where I used an image map and JavaScript to display different information based on the user's choice.

projects.name: Mackinac Island Website
description: I worked on this website for both the midterm and final projects for my Web II class.  Inspiration for the color scheme came from the Victorian trim on the mostly white houses of downtown Mackinac, and features of note are the DHTML on the natural attractions page and the responsive design of the website.  The blog (built with PHP) does not work correctly on this server because it isn't set up to access the database that is located on a different server.  I may fix this in the future.

projects.name: Select a Fish Dynamic Option Creation
description: This project, for my client-side programming course, focused on the dynamic creation of options following a user's selection.  My favorite parts of this project are the bubble and fish animations and the graphics, which I created using PowerPoint.  This seems an unusual choice of program but the results were exactly as I wished the images to appear and there's a bit of a story behind my PowerPoint drawing skills (click on the image on my home page for more details).

projects.name: Java Trouble Game
description: This started out as a group project until my partner dropped the class early on.  As a result, I ended up completing it on my own.

The final product is a multi-player game that is based off of the board game Trouble and is played on one device.  My version is similar to the original in the determination of the beginning player, the operation of turns, and the general rules of the game.  The only differences are in board size and the number of pieces that players move from start to finish.

The most difficult aspects of implementation were the tie-breaker scenario during the determination of the starting player, the logic behind turn-taking and move validation, and the handling of all the possible cases that could occur as a player's piece nears and enters the finish spaces.  Click the image to the left to download the executable version of this game.
directions: Click here to download a jar file of the game (trouble_game.jar)
Follow the directions to determine which player will go first

Enjoy! Note that if you move your cursor to the bottom right of the window on the left, it'll turn into a pointer.  Clicking will give you game directions (I'm not sure what happened to the help icon and may look into that later)

projects.name: Java Mancala Game
description: For my final project for my second Java course at RIT, I worked in a group of four to create a networked game based off of Mancala.  We worked well together, and the finished game both looks good and functions as it should, with the exception of a few self-correcting bugs that likely result from a problem with the sending or receiving of data between client and server.  The primary challenge in the creation of this game was the interaction between the server and the client - more specifically, the receipt and processing of the data received by either end of the connection.
directions: Click here to download a zip file of the game's components
Unzip the file and run the surver by opening the MancalaServer.jar file
If both clients were opened on the same device, you can use the default "localhost" server IP for both.  Otherwise, use the IP address of the device that you ran the server on.
Enjoy! The second client to join will go first.

projects.name: IST Windows Form
description: This project involved retrieving json data from an api (www.ist.rit.edu/api) and displaying it on a Windows form using C♯ in Visual Studio.
directions: Click here to download a zip file of the application's components
Unzip the file and run Project3.exe (it should have a particularly unique icon compared to the other files)

projects.name: Explore the Walters App
description: This app provides information on the artwork on display at the Walters Art Museum in addition to details on events taking place at the museum, admission and tours, and social media.  The Explore the Walters App was created using the Ionic framework for cross-platform app development. Right now I've only generated the Android version but may generate the iOS app in the future.
directions: Click here to download the app
Install the app on your android phone and run

skills.name: Java (JGrasp & Eclipse)
skills.description: I took two courses in Java (using the Eclipse environment) at my high school and passed the AP Computer Science test with a 5.  I've taken two more courses in Java (using JGrasp) at RIT and have worked as a teaching assistant for both.  In two additional courses, I've used Java to access and alter data in a database and to build SOAP and RESTful services.  I'm accustomed to using the Java APIs to figure out classes that I am not familiar with and am comfortable explaining object oriented programming concepts or my ideas when it comes to solving problems using Java.

skills.name: HTML5 & CSS3
skills.description: I have a good grasp of HTML5 and CSS3 after taking three web courses at RIT and building numerous websites that reinforced my knowledge of the languages.

skills.name: JavaScript
skills.description: I'm confident in my knowledge of JavaScript, am familiar with several frameworks, and have experience using the language for animation, dynamic element creation, sorting and filtering, compatibility checking, and local storage.

skills.name: jQuery
skills.description: I first learned and used jQuery for a client programming class project.  Since then, I've used it to continuously update and manage the interactive elements of a website I created during my internship at UPMC and to display project and skill information pulled from a json data file for this website.

skills.name: Ionic Framework and Angular.js
skills.description: I know the Ionic framework fairly well from using it to develop a cross-platform mobile app for a class.  My knowledge of Angular doesn't extend any farther than its role in Ionic.  I should be able to recognize and make sense of the framework's operations/characteristics and plan on looking into it more in the future.

skills.name: Node.js
skills.description: I used Node.js to write skills for Amazon's Alexa Voice Service as part of my software engineering internship with UPMC.  I'm fairly comfortable with the framework but feel as if I could use some more experience with it.

skills.name: Alexa Voice Service Skills
skills.description: This was the focus of the projects that I worked on over the course of my internship with UPMC Enterprises.  I know what goes into the creation of a new Alexa skill and how to deploy and test it using AWS Lambda and Amazon's Alexa Skills Kit.

skills.name: Jasmine Testing Framework
skills.description: I have a fairly basic knowledge of the Jasmine JavaScript testing framework from my internship at UPMC and an interest in learning more.

skills.name: PHP
skills.description: The server programming course I recently completed covered PHP extensively so I now know how to use it to write classes, access and alter data in a database, validate and sanitize data, parse XML and JSON, build, deploy, and access a SOAP or RESTful service, or maintain state using cookies, sessions, form fields, or url

skills.name: Databases...SQL (MySQL)
skills.description: I have some experience pulling data from and adding data to a MySQL database using PHP from one of my web courses and from a project I worked on as a software engineering intern for UPMC.  Thanks to a database class, I know the process that goes into designing and implementing a database and how to draw and interpret E-R diagrams.  I know the basic SQL commands and can use that knowledge to create and update tables and select and perform functions on data.

skills.name: C♯ & Visual Studio
skills.description: For a client-side programming class project, I used C♯ to consume json data from a web service and display it on a windows form.  I've also used it a little in other classes to access and alter data in a database and to build and deploy a SOAP and RESTful service.  I feel as if I know my way around the Visual Studio interface and, while I have not had as much experience with C♯ as I've had with Java, I'm confident that I can figure out how to perform different types of tasks with it.

skills.name: Git
skills.description: I wrote Git commands on the Mac Terminal to access and maintain a repository on GitLab for my work for my summer internship at UPMC.  I've also used Git Bash to push changes to a group class project and to this website.

skills.name: Adobe Photoshop
skills.description: I've taken two courses on Photoshop at RIT.  I'm nowhere near being a Photoshop "master" but I know my way around the interface and tools and would be able to pick up anything I don't know how to do from tutorials.

skills.name: Adobe Illustrator
skills.description: The two classes I took on Photoshop also covered Illustrator some.  As a result, I am adept at using the pen tool, in particular, and know my way around the Illustrator interface.

skills.name: Adobe InDesign
skills.description: I used InDesign once for a class project (designing a recipe book), so I understand the basics of the program and can build on that more in the future if needed.

skills.name: Wireframing & Prototyping
skills.description: I've used Sketch, Balsamiq, and NinjaMock for wireframing and InVision and Principle for prototyping in various classes.  I'm competent with all the tools but have varying amounts of experience with them and more to learn for some.

skills.name: Visual Basic
skills.description: This was my first programming language.  I learned it during my freshman year of high school and haven't used it since, but should be able to pick it up again quickly if need be.

skills.name: Minitab Statistical Software
skills.description: I'm not so sure that I will find myself using this software in the future, but if it does come up, I know how to perform hypothesis testing on data with different characteristics using Minitab and am familiar with many of the functionalities that the program offers (thanks to my second Statistics course).

skills.name: SPSS Statistical Software
skills.description: I have experience entering, displaying, and running some tests on data from two research methods classes.
